natural problem: Pat is to select six cookies from a tray containing only chocolate chip, oatmeal, and peanut butter cookies. There are at least six of each of these three kinds of cookies on the tray. How many different assortments of six cookies can be selected? (Note that cookies of the same type are not distinguishable.)
natural solution: The numbers of the three types of cookies must have a sum of six. Possible sets of whole numbers whose sum is six are \[ 0,0,6;\ 0,1,5;\ 0,2,4;\ 0,3,3;\ 1,1,4;\ 1,2,3;\ \ \text{and}\ 2,2,2. \]Every ordering of each of these sets determines a different assortment of cookies.
There are 3 orders for each of the sets \[ 0,0,6;\ 0,3,3;\ \text{and}\ 1,1,4. \]There are 6 orders for each of the sets \[ 0,1,5;\ 0,2,4;\ \text{and}\ 1,2,3. \]There is only one order for $2,2,2$.
Therefore the total number of assortments of six cookies is $3\cdot 3 + 3\cdot 6 + 1 = \boxed{28}$.

assumes h0 : "chocolate_chip \<ge> 6"
and h1 : "oatmeal \<ge> 6"
and h2 : "peanut_butter \<ge> 6"
shows  "(\<Sum>(i, j, k) | i + j + k = 6. 1) = 28"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n = (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i + j + k = n. 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 6 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 2 choose 2"
shows  "f 6 = 28"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Pat is to select six cookies from a tray containing only chocolate chip, oatmeal, and peanut butter cookies. There are at least six of each of these three kinds of cookies on the tray. How many different assortments of six cookies can be selected? (Note that cookies of the same type are not distinguishable.) The final Answer is 28
 ### Proof

 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. f n = (\<Sum> (i, j, k) | i + j + k = n. 1)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 6 \<longrightarrow> f n = n - 2 choose 2"
shows  "f 6 = 28"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Let $f(n)$ represent the number of ways to represent the integer $n$ as a sum of three non-negative integers, i.e., $f(n) = \sum_{i+j+k=n} 1$. Find the value of $f(6)$ for all integers $n \geq 6$, given that $f(n) = {n-2 \choose 2}$ for all $n \geq 6$. The final answer is $28$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and assortments :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 6 \<longrightarrow> assortments k = binomial_coefficient (k + 2) 2"
shows  "assortments n = 28"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Pat is to select six cookies from a tray containing only chocolate chip, oatmeal, and peanut butter cookies. There are at least six of each of these three kinds of cookies on the tray.  Therefore the total number of assortments of six cookies is $3\cdot 3 + 3\cdot 6 + 1 = \boxed{28}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and assortments :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. k \<ge> 6 \<longrightarrow> assortments k = binomial_coefficient (k + 2) 2"
shows  "assortments n = 28"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A function is defined as follows: for a given natural number $n$, the number of assortments $a(n)$ equals the binomial coefficient of $(n + 2)$ choose $2$ when $n \geq 6$. What is the value of $a(6)$? The final answer is $28$.

and h3 : "n = 6"
shows  "card { (C, O, P). C + O + P = n \<and> C \<le> n_C \<and> O \<le> n_O \<and> P \<le> n_P } = 28"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

theorem
fixes chocolate_chip oatmeal peanut_butter :: nat
assumes h0 : "chocolate_chip \<ge> 6"
and h1 : "oatmeal \<ge> 6"
and h2 : "peanut_butter \<ge> 6"
and h3 : "combinations = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..6}. \<Sum>j\<in>{0..6}. card {k. k \<le> 6 - i - j \<and> i + j + k = 6})"

 Therefore the total number of assortments of six cookies is $3\cdot 3 + 3\cdot 6 + 1 = \boxed{28}$.
